results.notes:
IN PROGRESS

Spore Print – Medium Brown (slight orange red tint)

Smell – very mild

Habitat – Oak Woods with some Sweet Gum, cedar, Elm

(specimens were dry, no stickiness noted – but this is coming out of heavy rains which may have washed off any slime.)

Cap – Convex to flat with many splits as it matures, lighter at edge, umbo. Top smooth – context thin, same color as cap. Dry.

Gills – darkened by spore, ragged edges, close, attached to stipe but pulling away in maturity.

Stipe – fibrous, hollowing. whitish coating near the base. Rooted in ground mixed with forest material. No foot or swelling at base. Dry. No evidence of a partial veil or cortina.

Microscopy – see photos – Aquaduct section and gill longitudinal cross section. I saw basidia with 4 attachment points. I saw short basidioles not much longer than the basidia. I saw no cysts on the tip of the gill in either the aquaduct cross section of the longitudinal gill cross section. I saw no clamp connections. Viewed in H2O, the spores were golden brown.

Spores – Finely spined. Shape – subfusiform.

results.notes:
Ganoderma resinaceum Boud.
Lacquered Bracket, DE: Harziger Lackporling
Slo.: smolena pološčenka

Code: Bot_908/2015_DSC8633

Habitat: Alpine pasture; moderately incline mountain slope; southeast aspect; calcareous, stony, colluvial ground; shallow soil layer; full sun, dry and relatively warm place; exposed to direct rain; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 625 m (2.050 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: at the base of dead stump of a stand alone, cut down, mostly decorticated Ostrya carpinifolia.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, ‘Na melu’ place, near Trenta 2b cottage, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: According to keys of genus Ganoderma published in Ryvarden (2014) and Bernicchia (2005) this find fits well to Ganoderma resinaceum. It has distinctly stipitate pileus, continuous, partly shiny and reddish-brown (not dark brown and dull as with Ganoderma applanatum and Ganoderma australe) resinous crust, which first melts and then burns with a yellow flame when heated at the tip of a knife in the flame of a match and a darker line in context just above tube layer. However, some traits not mentioned in the keys pose problems. The context color doesn’t seem to correspond well to the descriptions in Ryvarden (2014) and Krieglsteiner (2000) (‘pale grayish-brown’) and Bernicchia (2005) (‘brown, red-brown’). The find was found on dead stump of Ostrya carpinifolia (host species not listed as a possible substrate in the literature available to me) while Ganoderma resinaceum is known from live deciduous trees. Measured spores are slightly too long and too wide in average compared to most published data (the only exception is Ref.: 4). Their width fits better to similar Ganoderma pfeifferi, which is apparently always sessile and never stipitate. Measured spore dimensions actually fit perfectly to Ganoderma carnosum, which is, however, know only from conifers. Also the habitat of the find seems strange. Ganoderma resinaceum is usually found in parks, roadsides, seldom in woods. All this makes my determination uncertain to some extent.

Growing solitary; pileus dimensions 10 × 8 cm; oozing reddish droplets when cut, pore layer bruising brown when handled; trama fibrous-corky and very firm, difficult to cut even with a ceramic knife; taste bitter, smell distinctive, pleasant, a kind of mushroomy; SP faint, possibly brown.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
UPDATE: Going through the keys on MushroomExpert, this seems to be closest to Mycena epipterygia var. lignicola or Mycena epipterygia. However, I don’t think it is either one of these. (looking at the spores may help – but not tonight)

Habitat: wooded area, in the moss growing on the north side of a very large Loblolly Pine on the side of a tiny intermittent stream.

Photos – debris on the surfaces result due to the stickiness.

Spore Print – White

Spore Dimensions – TBD

Smell: didn’t notice any. Later crushed a cap. It had a distinctive odor, but just the odor of the woods – not an unusual odor, not spicey, radishy, or other.
Taste: did not

Cap: Thin, translucent, sticky. Olive-yellow color. Bell shape – see photos. 1.5 cm diameter.

Gills: olive yellow tone like stipe. See image. Attached to stalk but pulling free at maturity. Thin, sub-distant to close.

Stipe: 2 X width of cap. Olive-yellow on the middle and upper section, sticky, hollow. Rooted, relatively long root. Lower section of stipe is darker with a reddish tint. Stipe shows a bit of clear liquid when cut but no other liquid.

Microscopic Features -

Stipe section – a thin cross section was taken making a ring ( as the stipe was hollow). The ring was cut in half. The half was flattened and a thin cross section taken. I don’t think this is a good way. The resulting images show what appears to be long cysts that take the fushia stain. ( However, these may be nimatodes or something else.) see image

Spore images: TBD

Cap: Aquaduct section. See image of one cyst that pulled free. Notice think basidium appendages that hold the developing spores. All basisia appeared to have this stout structure. Also, large cysts were seen of clavate shape – 10 microns by 30-35 microns.

results.notes:
Collected under large Loblolly Pines.

Stout appearance. Caps are about 3 cm across. Twisted Stipe, 1 cm thick.

Spore Print – white

Spore microscopy – first attempt failed. Second measured spores. Measurements were made by fitting an ellipse around the spore including spines. Longest spines were measured to be around 1 – 1.2 micron based on the 6 spores photographed.

see photos.

Measurements of 4 spores, microns.
| Major| Minor| Q |
1 | 8.42 | 8.16 | 1.03 |
2 | 7.83 | 7.32 | 1.07 |
3 | 7.15 | 6.88 | 1.04 |

results.notes:
Dear colleagues,

i am in doubd identifiying a species (Physalacriaceae, Omphalotaceae probably) that has several important features but it does not help me to assign it to any known to me genus. I am sorry that i was lazy to make photos of microstructures in vital state, since the purplish-brown cystidia here were very spectacular. But the pigment crumbled and changed its color after drying.

Frb collybioid, growing in a group 10 nearby, cap up to 5 cm across, thin, convex to plant with shallow depression in centre, purplish-gray with brownish centre, smooth, or with scarce fibrillose purplish scales at the edge when young, striate for 1/2, hygrophanous in centre; gills purplish-gray, with purple edge, rare (L=20), with lamellulae and with low anastomoses; stem up to 10 cm long, 0.5 cm thick, not or slightly rooting, hollow, twisted, whitish, fibrillose, with purlish outer loose fibrillose ridges and scales.

Pileipellis a cutis, outer layer hyphae encrusted with brown pigment; caulipellis similar, with clamps; cheilo- and pleurocystidia abundant, fusoid, with obtuse uppper part, thin-walled with purplish-brown pigmented content (well seen in vital state, crumbles after dessication in water and dissolves in KOH), about 60 mk long, 10 mk broad; spores hyaline, smooth, ellipsoid, 7 (6.5-7.5) x 3.8 (3.5-4.2), Q=1.6-2.
In mixed aspen-birch forest with conifers in admixture grown after clear cut, West Siberian middle taiga zone (61,06646N 69,45351E).

Could you suggest any ideas?
Nina.

results.notes:
Hello, I’m trying to identify this beautiful mushroom growing from a maple log in my backyard. The log is more like one of the main branches from an enormous silver maple. It’s huge and unmovable, about 300lbs, dropped into my yard from neighbours’ yard when they removed their silver maple in winter 2013. I originally inoculated the log with shiitake plugs in spring-summer 2014, but this is not shiitake, so something else established itself first. This mushroom does no look like any of the other mushrooms we are cultivating in our yard (shiitake, maitake, lion’s mane, phoenix oyster) all grown from plug spawn from a reputable supplier.

Characteristics (see photos):

  • no peculiar smell, just smells like earthy musky sweet mushrooms
  • flush appeared only after temperatures dropped into 50s w/ lows in 30s late this November, there is a second flush maturing now (see photos)
  • growing on silver maple, very much still intact (log is not decayed, nothing else is growing on the log)
  • cap is orangy-creamy-brownish, ranges is diameter from about 1-4cm, flattens as matures with the larger ones flaring outward slightly
  • cap is smooth but gets slippery when wet and tacky as it dries, almost feels like a slight gel coating when it’s wet
  • gills are creamy white, come up to the stem but don’t attach to it or run down its length
  • stem starts out creamy coloured like the gills, but then turns a deep brownish-black from the base upwards as it matures
  • stem at maturity is brownish-black with tiny hairs that feel like velvet
  • flush appears with multiple mushrooms in tight cluster
  • spore print shows white spores in the pattern of the gills with little outward spray (see photo)
  • looks like some critters have been eating from it

If anyone could assist identifying it, I would greatly appreciate the help.

results.notes:
Code: Bot_923/2015_DSC9658

Habitat: steep grassland, extensively used; south aspect; calcareous ground; under a group of three large Larix decidua trees; dry, sunny place (but in shade of a mountain during winter months); partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 5 -7 deg C, elevation 850 m (2.800 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: soil under Larix decidua.

Place: Zadnjica valley, right bank of Krajcerca stream bed, at the foot of Mt. Pihavec, near the uppermost cottage in the valley, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Hygrophorus lucorum is not a common species but it is easy to recognize. It is unequivocally characterized by its habitat under Larix decidua on calcareous ground and its vivid lemon yellow to gold-yellow color of pilei, which cannot be overlooked in green grassland. Growing solitary and in small groups, over twenty pilei found; pilei diameter 1.8 – 4.5 cm, up to 1.5 cm high; stipe from 3.8 to 4.5 cm tall and of 8 to 9 mm in diameter; taste mild mushroomy; smell mild, pleasant, mushroomy; SP whitish with a yellow tint, oac14.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Habitat: under Slash Pine. growing on the ground. The ground is a mix of pine debris, sand and clay. Looking at over a dozen, none seemed to be growing connected directly to pine debris.

Smell: none detected
Taste: did not

Spore Print: medium orange, about the same color as the gills. NOT Brown or Rusty Brown

Spore Micrography: see images. Note that the surface of the spores was not smooth but appeared to have very minute surface ridges or undulations.

Cap:Inrolled, flattening with age. Some mature have a round shape, others irregular and some wavy or scalloped. No liquids from cap when cut or torn. Cap context tan with a wet look.

Gills: yellow-orange, close, adnate to decurrent. Ragged edges. Somewhat brittle but not as much as Russula or Lactarius.

Stipe – about 3/4 cm thick. Yellowish orange like gills but covered with a white patina. Rooted to grown with white mycelium. Stipe hollowing, particularly at the top. fibrous.
results.location_name: Gladewater Dam Park, Gladewater, Upshur Co., Texas, USA

results.notes:
Code: Bot_787/2014_DSC0179

Habitat: mixed wood edge; Fagus sylvatica, Picea abies, Fraxinus ornus, Ostrya carpinifolia and Corylus avellana dominant; slightly inclined mountain slope; shallow, calcareous colluvial ground; relatively warm and dry place; partly protected by from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitations ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7-9 deg C, elevation 570 m (1.870 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: fallen off, dead, but still standing branch of Fraxinus ornus.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, right bank of river Soča, next to the trail from Trenta 2 farm house to Trenta 2b cottage, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC.

Comments: Daedaleopsis confragosa is a common fungus but a very plastic species with not yet settled taxonomy. Many mycologists split it into three species or subspecies Daedaleopsis confragosa, Daedaleopsis tricolor and rare Daedaleopsis septentrionalis. They don’t differ microscopically. But, indeed one can find strikingly different specimens having from small, vividly and beautifully red pilei to dirt whitish and pale beige-brown examples with any possible kind of pore surface one can imagine, from purely lamellate or elongated pores, sometimes labyrinthine to purely poroid. Taking into account only macroscopic traits it is hard to believe for a laymen that all these forms are one and the same species. The find photographed is interesting because of its unusual round form. Daedaleopsis confragosa is usually broadly attached, bracket like form.

Growing solitary; pileus diameter 4 – 4.5 cm and 1.5 cm thick; characteristic reddish bruising of pore surface not seen, possibly because the pileus was already quite old; SP whitish, lightly beige, oac900.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8

results.notes:
Habitat mostly Live Oak..
Caps up to 8.8 cm across and viscid.
Flesh of cap was whitish with vinaceous edges.
5% KOH on cap and stem was red.
5% KOH on flesh neg to sl. vinaceous.
Spores 11.0-15.0 X 6.2-8.9 microns and rough.
Q(avg) = 1.68 n=34
Initially I was going to call these C. vellingae or maybe C. xanthodryophilus. However the spores are too large for both and the KOH reactions seemed to favor the latter with even smaller spores.
I repeated the spore measurements(once in KOH and once in water)
and got very similar numbers.
Except for the apparent habitat, these fit C. elegantio-occidentalis pretty closely.

results.notes:
This is a slightly strange one that I’m not totally sure about – most everything looks good for A. hondensis (small, fawn-colored cap scales, faint phenolic odor, relatively weak yellowing, and thick felty partial veil), but it was growing in a very open, disturbed habitat (I usually find A. hondensis deeper in woods), and it was fruiting right alongside the moelleri/praeclaresquamosus/deardorffensis types. Usually A. hondensis fruits later.

Unfortunately I don’t think any specimens survived the class I taught that night.

results.notes:
Found these specimens (and 1 more specimen belonging to the same species) in a moist forest. All specimens between 1 and 2 m height on green leaves, with hosts (wasps) biting the leaf edge. Very distinctive appearance, with 3 different types of protruding ‘stalks’.
Uncompressed images of specific parts are available on request. In situ image of other specimen also available.
I haven’t been able to find online photos of anything resembling it, and a request on a Facebook page resulted only in “Hirsutella sp. maybe”.

On a side note: the form gives me notification that the camera date of my photo doesn’t match the observation date. That is incorrect, it does match. It may have intermingled the camera date with the modification date, in which case the MO-software probably needs adjustment.

On a second side note: ‘Herbarium name’ and ‘Herbarium Id’ could by confusing, as the first can both mean ‘the name of the herbarium’ or ‘the name given to the specimen in the herbarium’ (the default option takes care of this), while ‘Herbarium Id’ can either mean the (bar)code under which the specimen is registered in the herbarium or the (scientific) name with which the specimen is labeled in the herbarium.

results.notes: Growing on an old and barely alive Salix that used to have Pleurotus on it, but that stopped fruiting about five years ago. This is the second year that the Hohenbuehelia has shown up, and it has had a very long fruiting season both years. This fall it first showed up in October, and is still producing fresh fruiting bodies as of 27 December 2015.

results.notes:
Inocybe cf. brevicystis (match on micro morphology mostly) mycenoides (too thick pleurocystidia) langei (too small spores) scabella (too long-thin pleurocystidia) hirtella (no smell match). UPDATE 2020: I. parvicystis seems a much better match, in regards to all aspects: ecology plus macro and micro morfology

Ecologia: Montado de sobreiro (Quercus suber), debaixo de outro Quercus sp. de pequeno porte. Solo arenoso. zona de pasto bovino e caprino.

Píleo: < 2,5 cm. Convexo a aplanado, por vezes irregular a semi-lobulado, não umbonado mas com por vezes com alto a dar uma aparência quase cónica. Rimoso, +/- higrófano. beige ocre, de tons pálidos a tons mais quentes alaranjados. Centro por vezes mais claro que a margem. Carne esbranquiçada.

Himenóforo: Lâminas adnexas, próximas, beiges-acizentadas com tonalidades castanhas muito claras.

Pé: < 4,5cm x <0,5 cm. Cilindrico, base +/- bolbosa, por vezes curvada. Esbranquiçado, com tonalidades ocre-avermelhadas com idade ou ao toque. Liso a muito finamente tomentoso, especialmente no ápice. Trama esbranquiçada.
Cheiro ligeiro espermático, mesmo depois de fechado numa pequena caixa. Sabor suave, fungico, muito ligeiramente acidico.

Microscopia: esporos ovoides-elipsoidais, amigdaliformes, cor castanho tabaco, com pseudo-poro apical. Pleurocistidios metulóides, parede bem grossa (até 4um) amarelada em KOH8% e NH3OH5%, com pequena estrutura apical cristalizada. Queliocistídios abundantes, parecidos com pleurocistídios. Caulocistidios não encontrados no terço inferior do pé, abundantes no terço superior do pé, de forma semelhante aos pleurocistidios mas com menor ou ausente estrutura cristalizada, talvez mais longos, mais claviformes-cilindricos e de parede possivelmente mais fina.

Esporos:
7.5 [9 ; 9.4] 11 × 4.9 [5.8 ; 6] 6.9 Âµm
Q = 1.2 [1.5 ; 1.6] 1.9 ; N = 80 ; C = 95%
Me = 9.2 × 5.9 Âµm ; Qe = 1.6

Pleurocistídios:
28.7 [34.7 ; 38.1] 44.1 × 7.6 [9.5 ; 10.6] 12.6 Âµm
Q = 2.4 [3.4 ; 3.9] 4.9 ; N = 20 ; C = 95%
Me = 36.4 × 10.1 Âµm ; Qe = 3.7

results.notes:
Complete post: http://cogumelosportugal.forum-livre.com/...

ECOLOGIA: Gregário em zona de pinhal e eucaliptal. Num trilho, num vale húmido, barrento, saprófito em madeira e agulhas de pinheiro morto, por vezes aparentando ser terrestre. Vegetação imediatamente envolvente à base de silvas, tojo e outra vegetação rasteira.

CHAPÉU: <2,5cm. Convexo-hemisférico a aplanado com idade, ligeiramente umbonado, irregular-ondulado. Pequenas fibrilhas brunescentes (especialmente no centro) em fundo creme pálido por vezes com centro mais amarelo quente-laranja pálido. Margem ligeiramnete incurvada quando jovem com restos visíveis de véu tipo cortina. Pouco viscido a pegajoso quando molhado, a acetinado quando seco.

HIMÉNIO: Lâminas adnadas ligeiramente colaradas, cor de ocre amarelado a ocre-castanho com idade. Abundantes (~120 incluindo lâminas intermédias).

PÉ: <3cm x 0,5cm. Cilindrico, por vezes ligeiramente encurvado, de base mais grossa. Tomentoso (especialmente na base e quando jovem) da base até à zona anelar, concolor a castanho-quente (pela deposição de esporos), ápice creme-beige.

CARNE: Creme amarelada. Cheiro perfumado, farináceo, agradável. Sabor fungíco, férrico.

ESPORADA: castanho claro (pouca deposição)

MICROSCOPIA: Esporos ovóides a elipsóidais, por vezes quase cilindricos de uma cor amarelo-verde claro sub-hialino em KOH4%. Ornamentação presente (mas para já não resolvida), parede grossa. Basídios tetraspóricos, subhialinos, esverdeados-amarelados em KOH4%, de conteúdo visível/heterogénio, principalmente em azul de toluidina. Pleurocistídios como leptocistídios, claviformes a utriformes, ramente proeminentes ou de dimensões maiores que os basídios, sub-hialinos de um verde-amarelo claro em KOH4%. Aresta das lâminas aparentemente estéreis, de uma coloração geral significativamente mais amarelada que a pleura. Queilocistídios clafiformes a utriformes, de leptocistídios hialinos a crisocistídios (ou de coloração claramente mais amarela que pleurocistídios em KOH), de cor azul escuro em azul de algodão. Trama himenial paralela. Pileipelis de aparente ixocutis filamentosa com hifas estreitas, subhialinas, inseridas numa camada amarela e finalmente castanha. Ansas de anastomose presentes.

ECOLOGIA: terrestre; pinhal arenoso (Pinus pinaster) com outra vegetação rasteira. Semi-perturbado.

CHAPÉU: <1,3cm; cónico-campanulado; mamelonado; castanho escuro quase preto, higrófano; margem estriada.

HIMÉNIO: lâminas castanho-claras a castanho-rosadas; próximas; com lâminas intermédias

PÉ: <6cm x <0,2cm; frágil, ápice ligeiramente mais claro ou concolor, base com micélio branco (<1cm)

ESPORADA: cor de rosa

CHEIRO/SABOR: cheiro indiferente; sabor doce depois a ferro

MICROSCOPIA: esporos angulares hexagonais (<8,5 µm) com apículo quase sempre visível; cistidios raros, clavados a utriformes?

results.notes:
Found on Skyline Trail, near the trailhead, growing on a log (Douglas fir or redwood).

Basidia 4-spored (41-50)+(6-11) x (9-11). Spores 10-13 × 6-7. Cheilocystidia forming a sterile band 50-57 × 10-13, but also wider, and irregularly shaped. Hyphae of the pileipellis gelatinized, those of stipitipellis not gelatinized. Caulocystidia numerous and quite decorated with cylindrical or irregularly shaped excrescences. Clamps present, but not staring at you.

I’m puzzled by the variability of micro-features in several collections of M. purpureofusca that I looked at. The differences with the Perry & Desjardin’s M. bulliformis nom. prov. are not clear cut in my mind. I have Perry’s description (without drawings) of the new species, where he points out “more ornamented cheilocystidia” as a distinguisher, but also states that the pp hyphae in M. bulliformis are not embedded in gelatinous matter. (Almost) caespitose habit might speak in favor of M. bulliformis too.
